Virial - Activity coefficient ModelÂ¶

This class is focused for phase equilibrium using a virial correlation for the vapor phase and a activity coefficient model for the liquid phase. For the gas phase, the virial coefficient can be estimated using Abbott or Tsonopoulos correlations, also an ideal gas option is available. For liquid phase, NRTL, Wilson, Redlich - Kister and Modified-UNIFAC model are available.

  • Virial EoS
    • Ideal gas
    • Abbott - Van Ness
    • Tsonopoulos
  • Activity coefficient models
    • NRTL
    • Wilson
    • Redlich Kister
    • UNIFAC

Before creating a model object, it is necessary to supply the interactions parameters of the activity coefficient model. The mixture object is designed to store these parameters, as for example for the NRTL model.

>>> from phasepy import virialgamma
>>> mix = mixture(ethanol, water)
>>> alpha = np.array([[0.       , 0.5597628],
...       [0.5597628, 0.       ]])
>>> g = np.array([[  0.       , -57.6880881],
...       [668.682368 ,   0.       ]])
>>> g1 = np.array([[ 0.        ,  0.46909821],
...       [-0.37982045,  0.        ]])
>>> #Adding activity model parameters
>>> mix.NRTL(alpha, g, g1)
>>> #Creating Model
>>> model = virialgamma(mix, virialmodel = 'Abbott', actmodel = 'nrtl' )
>>> #Model parameters are saved in actmodelp attribute
>>> parameters = model.actmodelp
>>> np.all(parameters[0] == alpha), np.all(parameters[1] == g), np.all(parameters[2] == g1)
(True, True, True)

If you would like to use fitted parameters of a Redlich Kister expansion you can do it as follows:

>>> C0 = np.array([ 1.20945699, -0.62209997,  3.18919339])
>>> C1 = np.array([  -13.271128,   101.837857, -1100.29221 ])
>>> #Parameters are calculated as C = C0 + C1/T
>>> mix.rk(C0, C1)
>>> #Creating model
>>> model = virialgamma(mix, actmodel = 'rk' )
>>> #Readimg parameters
>>> parameters = model.actmodelp
>>> np.all(parameters[0] == C0), np.all(parameters[1] == C1)
(True, True)

If we would like to use the group contribution model UNIFAC with an ideal gas, the same class can be used.

>>> #Reading UNIFAC database
>>> mix.unifac()
#Creating Model
>>> model = virialgamma(mix, virialmodel = 'ideal_gas', actmodel = 'unifac')
class virialgamma(mix, virialmodel='Tsonopoulos', actmodel='nrtl')[source]Â¶

Bases: object

Creates a model with mixture using a virial eos to describe vapour phase and an activity coefficient model for liquid phase.

Parameters

  • mix (object) â mixture created with mixture class

  • virialmodel (string) â function to compute virial coefficients, available options are âTsonopoulosâ, âAbbottâ or âideal_gasâ

  • actmodel (string) â function to compute activity coefficients, available optiones are ânrtlâ, âwilsonâ, âunifacâ, ârkbâ or ârkâ

logfugef: computes effective fugacity coefficients

logfugef(X, T, P, state)

Method that computes the effective fugacity coefficients at given composition, temperature and pressure.

Parameters

  • X (array_like, mole fraction vector) â

  • T (absolute temperature in K) â

  • P (pressure in bar) â

  • state ('L' for liquid phase and 'V' for vapour phase) â

Returns

  • logfug (array_like) â effective fugacity coefficients

  • v0 (float) â volume of phase, if calculated
